steps.title: Set the yarmulke on the crown of your head.
steps.content: Set the yarmulke on the crown of your head. Unfold your yarmulke and set it on top of your head. Make sure it covers the crown, the area near the back center of your head, completely. Don’t let your yarmulke come too far forward or cover any of your forehead. [2] X Research source If there’s a design on your yarmulke, make sure it’s right-side up.

steps.title: Press down on your yarmulke to help it stick.
steps.content: Press down on your yarmulke to help it stick. Once you have the yarmulke in place, press lightly down on it so the fabric contacts your hair. The fabric should catch on your hair and keep the yarmulke on your head. This helps the hold your yarmulke in place so it doesn’t move around throughout the day. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Secure the yarmulke to your hair with bobby pins if it falls off.
steps.content: Secure the yarmulke to your hair with bobby pins if it falls off. Smaller yarmulkes may slip more than larger ones. Slide a bobby pin onto one side of the yarmulke and secure some of your hair underneath it. If 1 bobby pin isn’t enough to keep your yarmulke in place, put another pin on the other side as well. [4] X Research source Wear bobby pins if you plan on being active, such as playing sports or exercising.

steps.title: Wear your yarmulke at all times if you’re an Orthodox Jew.
steps.content: Wear your yarmulke at all times if you’re an Orthodox Jew. Although it’s not required by law, Orthodox Jews wear yarmulkes throughout the day. When you start your morning, put on your yarmulke right away. You may cover your yarmulke with another hat, such as a fedora if you’d like, but it’s not required. [5] X Trustworthy Source Chabad.org Online resource for information related to Chabad-Lubavitch and Jewish culture Go to source You don’t have to wear your yarmulke while you’re bathing or sleeping.

steps.title: Put your yarmulke on during synagogue, on holidays, or when saying blessings.
steps.content: Put your yarmulke on during synagogue, on holidays, or when saying blessings. If you don’t want to wear your yarmulke throughout the entire day, put it on during special ceremonies or holidays. Keep it on your head whenever you attend the synagogue or recite prayers as a sign of respect for God. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Don’t wear your yarmulke in public if it’s not safe to in your area.
steps.content: Don’t wear your yarmulke in public if it’s not safe to in your area. Some areas and countries aren’t safe to wear a yarmulke in public due to antisemitic attacks. [7] X Research source If you live in one of these areas, keep your yarmulke on at home and take it off when you go out unless you’re going to the synagogue. [8] X Research source Try wearing a yarmulke underneath another hat if you still want to have one on.

steps.title: Pick a white or multicolored yarmulke if you follow modern Jewish practices.
steps.content: Pick a white or multicolored yarmulke if you follow modern Jewish practices. Many modern Jewish people choose yarmulkes that are white or have designs sewn onto them. Look for a design you like and choose a yarmulke that fits your head well. Try a suede, knit, or leather yarmulke to see what material you prefer. [9] X Research source Silk yarmulkes tend to denote the lowest level of observance since they’re usually given out during ceremonies if you don’t already own one.

steps.title: Choose a dark-colored yarmulke if you are a traditional Jew.
steps.content: Choose a dark-colored yarmulke if you are a traditional Jew. Darker colors, such as black, navy blue, or grey, usually mean you follow more traditional Jewish practices. Pick a yarmulke that’s leather, crocheted, or suede that fits well on top of your head. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Pick a black velvet yarmulke if you’re a Haredi Orthodox Jew.
steps.content: Pick a black velvet yarmulke if you’re a Haredi Orthodox Jew. Haredi Orthodox Jews are conservative socially, politically, and religiously and oppose secular lifestyles. [11] X Research source Look for a yarmulke that’s made of black velvet that’s about the size of a salad plate since this is the most traditional style. Make sure the yarmulke doesn’t slip or fall off your head while you wear it. [12] X Research source Avoid wearing a black velvet yarmulke if you don’t want to be confused as a Haredi Orthodox Jew.

steps.title: Wear a crocheted or wire yarmulke if you’re a woman.
steps.content: Wear a crocheted or wire yarmulke if you’re a woman. While women don’t need to cover their head with a yarmulke, you can choose to wear one if you want. Many yarmulkes designed for women are made with wires and beads to look feminine. Look for a design that you like and try it on to see if it fits your head well. [13] X Research source
